description: The phase flip channel randomly applies a Pauli Z operation with probability p, flipping the relative phase between |0⟩ and |1⟩. It is the Hadamard-conjugate of the bit flip channel: a phase flip in the computational basis is equivalent to a bit flip in the Hadamard (X) basis.

While the populations (diagonal elements) of the density matrix remain unchanged, the off-diagonal coherences are damped by a factor of (1-2p). At p=0.5, all coherence is destroyed and the channel becomes a full Z-dephasing channel.
The phase flip channel is a Pauli channel and can be exactly corrected by PEC with a known error rate. It is also naturally suppressed by dynamical decoupling sequences that refocus Z-type errors.

properties.Classical analog: No direct classical analog (purely quantum effect)

physical_examples: Fluctuating qubit frequencies causing random Z rotations
Stray magnetic fields along the quantization axis
Charge noise in superconducting transmon qubits
qem_considerations: Dynamical decoupling (spin echo, CPMG) effectively refocuses phase flip errors
Pauli twirling preserves Z-error structure; can symmetrize into depolarizing noise
PEC can exactly cancel phase flip noise with a known error rate p
Detectable by X-basis parity checks in stabilizer codes
